entry.title: SAP Ariba Procure to Order 2508 Release Key Innovations
entry.content:
Hello, SAP Ariba Community! We're thrilled to reveal some fantastic new innovations in our upcoming release, 2508, including the much-anticipated initial release of Joule—our digital AI copilot in Guided Buying. Additionally, we have more exciting updates to share regarding WalkMe enhancements, improvements to the Mobile experience, and advancements in virtual card capabilities. Stay tuned for these highlights!

AI Copilot Joule in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-1163)

We're excited to introduce Joule, SAP's generative AI copilot, now available in Guided Buying. Joule features a conversational interface designed to help users complete tasks efficiently. It leverages generative and other AI technologies to understand natural language requests, identify user intent, perform actions, and provide valuable insights.

With Joule, you can easily access information such as:

  • Requisition approval status
  • Requisition details
  • Recent purchases

You can find the Joule panel by clicking on the icon at the top of your screen. This release is just the beginning of our journey to harness AI across buying processes, driving significant efficiency gains and more for our entire user base.

 Please note that AI copilot Joule in Guided Buying will be in Early Access until September 19th, 2025 at which time it will be made generally available to customers

For more detailed information please see this blog: Joule in SAP Ariba Applications

Enhancements to WalkMe in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-1266)

We were excited to announce the first iteration of WalkMe in Guided Buying in the last release (2505), now to build on this momentum with an important user experience enhancement.

The WalkMe Digital Adoption Platform is now enabled for all Guided Buying customers and the WalkMe panel can now display content from SAP Companion also through some subtle UI changes.

If both WalkMe and SAP Companion are enabled, the walk me panel now displays a separate tab for each respectively:

 

Previously, WalkMe was disabled by default, and SAP Companion content displayed in a different panel.

This innovation offers more flexibility, allowing you to use the right resources and support at the right time in the most suitable way. It will help guide you seamlessly through your desired procurement processes and drive better outcomes.

 

Asset Management in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-915)

We're excited to introduce a new feature that brings enhanced asset management capabilities to Guided Buying. Here's what you need to know:

 Seamless Asset Management Integration

This feature enables you to manage assets directly in Guided Buying using the asset management functionality from your SAP ERP system. With this integration, you can now manage your organization's assets throughout their lifecycle, all within the familiar Guided Buying interface.

Streamlined Asset Workflow

When an asset manager is added to a purchase requisition, the request is automatically sent to the Asset Workbench for further classification. From there, you can easily assign asset-specific lines, asset groups, and monitor the status of your assets.

Easy Access to Asset Management

To make your asset management tasks even more convenient, we've added a dedicated Asset Workbench section right on the Guided Buying home page:

To submit purchase requisitions with assets and to manage assets in the Asset Workbench the user must belong to the Asset Manager Group.

Mass Editing of Accounting Information in SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile App (BMAA-472)

Users of the SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile App can now edit accounting information at the header level of a requisition through a new section called ‘Charge to’. This eliminates the need to edit accounting information for each line item—a process that could be particularly time-consuming for requisitions with multiple line items.

We understand that efficiency is key when you're buying on the go. This small but impactful change aims to streamline your overall mobile buying experience and save you valuable time.

Prepackaged Reports for Virtual Card Orders (PROC-1011)

We have created a new entry to the pre-packaged reports in to help analyse V-Card transactions and corresponding data.

The Virtual Card Reports folder contains the prepackaged reports for:

  • Virtual Card orders
  • Virtual Card Charges Load Report
  • Virtual Card Charge Reconciliation Report
  • Virtual Card Charge Exception Report

We believe these new reports will significantly enhance your ability to analyze and manage virtual card usage, leading to more informed decision-making and improved financial controls.

Stay tuned for more updates and innovations designed to empower your procurement processes!

entry.title: SAP UX Q3/2025 Update – Part 5: SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass
entry.content:
This fifth post in my series gives an overview of latest UX innovations in SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass, products for managing your spend (procurement) and external workforce. For SAP Ariba: Joule is now available for selected products, on-boarding guidance is provided by WalkMe, and we have some additional AI-assistance in SAP Ariba Category Management, amongst other enhancements. For SAP Fieldglass, Joule is now available too, and the SOW (Statement of Work) dashboard can now be adapted per user role, ensuring that users see what fits best for them. Also, you can now use generative AI for importing SOWs from documents.

 

SAP Ariba

Here are the recent UX innovations that I have picked:

  • On-boarding guidance via WalkMe Digital Adoption Platform.
  • Joule, our AI copilot, available for selected SAP Ariba products.
  • UX enhancements in Category Management: Supplier preferencing, Strategy and Plan enhancements for collaboration and AI-insights, plus some more minor enhancements in details.
  • Integration of the SAP User Research Panel into selected products’ built-in user feedback surveys.

On-boarding guidance via WalkMe

When new employees join the procurement team, we now make it easier for them to get up and running with SAP Ariba by providing enhanced step-by-step guidance on how to get typical tasks done in the system. With the 2508 release, we provide WalkMe for the following SAP Ariba products:

  • SAP Ariba Buying
  • SAP Ariba Buying and Invoicing
  • SAP Ariba Contracts
  • SAP Ariba Invoice Management
  • SAP Ariba Sourcing
  • SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance
  • SAP Ariba Supplier Risk

WalkMe offers engaging, intuitive, role-based guidance to help user quickly achieve value by minimizing barriers during initial use of the product and creating a great first experience. Figure 1 gives you an idea of what this looks like, showing first the list of activities available for the current user context within SAP Ariba Sourcing, and then an example of one of the guidance steps (the fourth step after the user had selected “Create a guided sourcing project”).

Figure 1: An example of WalkMe for SAP Ariba Sourcing. Alt Text: two cut-outs from screenshots are shown. On the left the WalkMe panel lists two options “Create a sourcing project” and “Create a guided sourcing event”. On the right, the UI for “Create guided sourcing project” is shown with a pop-over explaining the options for a selecting either a “Single event” or a “Full project”, and explaining why the system has pre-selected “Full project”.

In the guided sourcing capability for SAP Ariba Sourcing, Walkthroughs are available for the following tasks:

  • Create a guided sourcing project.
  • Create a guided souring event.
  • Create a guided sourcing event in a project.
  • Invite suppliers.

Check out the video below to see WalkMe in action in guided sourcing, and find out more in the documentation:

  • Video: Explore Guided Sourcing Events with WalkMe (3:35 min.)
  • Documentation: WalkMe Available in SAP Ariba Products.

You can go one step further and provide content tailored to your organization by purchasing WalkMe Premium for SAP Ariba Solutions. For more information about WalkMe Premium for SAP Ariba, visit the WalkMe home page.

Joule for SAP Ariba

With the 2508 release, Joule, our AI copilot, is now available for:

  • Supplier management.
  • Guided sourcing.
  • Guided buying.

Figure 2 shows an example of what it looks like when you open up Joule in guided buying, where it provides suggestions for what you could ask. These suggestions are clickable, but you can of course type in your text directly.

Figure 2: Joule for guided buying. Alt Text: An image showing Joule after it has been opened for the first time, with the text “Hello Jitesh, How can I guide you?” at the top. The bottom half contains the chat area, with the text “Get started with Joule” followed by a selection of five suggestions as clickable buttons, such as “Approvers of a requisition”, at the very bottom the input field for the user to message Joule is shown.

The currently availabe capabilities are listed in the documentation:

  • Joule Capabilities in Supplier Management.
  • Joule Capabilities in Guided Sourcing.
  • Joule Capabilities in Guided Buying.

Please note that AI copilot Joule in Guided Buying will be in Early Access until September 19th, 2025 at which time it is planned to be made generally available to customers.

UX Enhancements in SAP Ariba Category Management

This section covers UX enhancements for supplier preferencing, Strategy and Plan enhancements for collaboration and AI-insights, and provides a link to more UX enhancements in detail.

Supplier Preferencing

When buying from various suppliers, it’s good to know how these suppliers view their relationship with your company. Do they value your custom highly? Or at the opposite extreme, do they see you as a nuisance, i.e. low volume but high effort and hence unprofitable?

Supplier preferencing is an established approach that helps organizations understand how they are perceived by vendors. By leveraging this insight, businesses can strengthen supplier relationships, foster collaboration, and improve supply chain effectiveness.

Supplier preferencing involves evaluating how suppliers view a buying organization based on two key dimensions:

  • Attractiveness of Account: How appealing the buying organization is to the supplier, influenced by factors like reputation, growth potential, and ease of doing business.
  • Relative Value of Business: The monetary value or strategic importance the buying organization's spend brings to the supplier.

Each dimension can be assessed as “high” or “low”, resulting in four possible categories Core, Development, Nuisance and Exploitable, as explained in the

  • Documentation: Supplier Preferencing.

We now provide an intuitive user experience for buyers to apply supplier preferencing very easily, and get an easy to understand overview for each supplier and for each strategy and plan you have created for buying from that supplier. Figure 3 shows an example for a fictitious supplier called SpeedShip, where the outcome of assessments for various strategy and plans are shown.

Figure 3: Supplier preferencing example in SAP Ariba Category Management. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Develop Strategy and Plan app with a pop-over showing with a heading “SpeedShip”, below that four tabs “Overview”, “Performance”, “SWOT” and “Supplier Preferencing” (selected). The pop-over summarizes the supplier as “Nuisance”, with a timestamp of last update, and shows a list of Assessments.

Figure 4 shows an extract of the questionnaire which employees can fill out in order to assess the supplier preference.

Figure 4: Supplier preferencing questionnaire in SAP Ariba Category Management. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Develop Strategy and Plan app with a pop-over showing part of a Supplier Preferencing Assessment Questionnaire, with yes/no questions on the attractiveness of account, such as “Do you see our organization as a potential strategic partner in the industry?”.

Strategy and Plan: Collaborate Externally by Sharing Plans as PDF

Now, Category Managers can share their strategy and plan documents with stakeholders who do not have access to SAP Ariba Category Management, by exporting them to a PDF file.

Stakeholders can review the strategy and plan outside of SAP Ariba Category Management, provide input, follow its direction, and consider it when developing related strategies. The exported file contains the most relevant content from all tools organized into pages so it can also be used as slide deck. Figure 5 shows the export screen, with parts of the first two pages with text summary and details, and Figure 6 shows how charts and tables are nicely presented as a page within the PDF file.

Figure 5: Creating a PDF file for the category strategy and plan within SAP Ariba Category Management, for sharing with stakeholders. Alt Text: A screenshot of the application Category Strategy and Plan with a pop-over for exporting to PDF. The left two thirds of the pop-over shows a preview of the PDF, showing the Strategy and Plan Summary, the right third shows settings for formatting and exporting.

Figure 6: An example PDF page from the exported category strategy and plan for sharing with stakeholders, from SAP Ariba Category Management. Alt Text: A screenshot showing a pop-over displaying one PDF page with eight cards, the top row of four cards showing charts for Spend, Top Suppliers, Top Regions, Top Subcategories, the bottom row showing lists for the values depicted in the charts.

AI-Assisted Summary for Strategy and Plan

As a category manager, you can use generative AI capabilities for generating a summary in the approval document. AI-enhanced summaries provide a quick overview, highlighting key points without the need to manually review details across all sections of the approval documents. You can refine these summaries and then submit the document for approval. Figure 7 shows an example of such a summary.

Figure 7: AI-generated strategy and plan summary in SAP Ariba Category Management. Alt Text: A screenshot of the Strategy Summary section of the Develop Strategy and Plan application, showing a full width editable text field containing text in sections “Market Dynamics”, “Category Segmentation”, “Cost Structures”. On the right above the section an AI button “Generate” is shown.

Additional enhancements

We have made some additional smaller enhancements to UI details, which improve the user’s experience. They are documented here:

  • SAP Ariba Category Management User Interface Enhancements.

Integration of the SAP User Research Panel

Getting feedback from the actual users of an application is key in order to continuously improve the user experience, and we are intensifying our efforts to reach the real users of our products, rather than the IT departmens who buy them. The SAP User Research Panel gives users the opportunity to sign-up to give feedback to SAP directly. We launched it nearly two years ago, see for example Your voice matters! Join the SAP User Research Panel. Since then many users across all areas have signed up.

We would like to encourage users of SAP Ariba to sign up too, and to make this easier, we have introduced a direct link to it from the user feedback survey. Users of SAP Ariba Category Management and SAP Ariba Supplier Risk occasionally receive a popup with a short survey asking for feedback on the product. Now, at the end of this survey, they are offered a link to sign up to the user resarch panel.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • SAP User Research Panel for SAP Ariba Category Management.
  • SAP User Research Panel for SAP Ariba Supplier Risk.

Further Information

For an overview of the key innovations with the 2508 release of SAP Ariba, have a look at this blog post:

  • SAP Ariba 2508 Release Key Innovations Preview.

 

SAP Fieldglass

Joule is now available for SAP Fieldglass, the Statement of Work (SOW) dashboard has been enhanced to allow role-specific customized views, and you can now use generative AI for importing SOWs from documents.

Joule for SAP Fieldglass

Our AI copilot Joule helps users for these specific activities:

  • Selecting job posting templates
  • Selecting statement of work templates
  • Completing work items
  • Viewing quarterly trends
  • Running reports
  • Closing workers
  • Searching help content

As an example of how Joule makes work easier for users, consider finding the right template for a job posting: rather than scanning through available templates, you can just give Joule the position or project, a description, and a few other details, and Joule will provide recommendations for which template to use. Once you have chosen a template, Joule can auto-populate some of the fields, speeding the process up for you.

You can also use Joule for analytical queries: as Joule to show you quarterly trends, and Joule will show you them in the form of graphs embedded within the Joule UI.

Figure 8 shows Joule when first opened in SAP Fieldglass, with hints as clickable buttons for what you can ask for.

Figure 8: Joule in SAP Fieldglass. Alt Text: An image showing Joule after it has been opened for the first time, with the text “Hello Jennifer, How can I guide you?” at the top. The bottom half contains the chat area, with the text “Get started with Joule” followed by a selection of five suggestions as clickable buttons, such as “Create Job Posting”, at the very bottom the input field for the user to message Joule is shown.

Look at the documentation for more information:

  • Joule in SAP Fieldglass

SOW Dashboard with Customizable Views

Effective Statement of Work (SOW) management requires real-time access to critical details like spend activity, service delivery progress, and pending action items. This helps track overall SOW progress, maintain budget control, and enable informed decision-making.  Last year, we introduced the SOW Dashboard, providing a comprehensive real-time view of critical SOW data (see my last year’s blog post).

Users in different business roles need to interact with the SOW, and each role has a unique set of details relevant to them for overseeing the health of the SOW. Now, the SOW dashboard supports customized views based on user roles, which streamlines the information displayed, so that users see only what is most relevant to them. Hence, they get a more focused and efficient experience tailored to their unique needs

Figure 9 shows an example of the SOW Dashboard set up for a user focused on project status and task management. Figure 10 shows an example for a user focused on financials and spend task management.

Figure 9: SAP Fieldglass SOW dashboard customized for users focused on project status and task management. Alt Text: A screenshot of SOW Dashboard showing four cards “SOW Activity Items”, “SOW Line Items”, “SOW Worker Activity Items” and “Upcoming SOW Worker End Dates”. The first three are represented as lists, with color-coded summaries of items that are critical and that have warnings, the fourth shows a 2D visualization with no. of SOW workers on the y-axis and time remaining (days) on the x-axis.

Figure 10: SAP Fieldglass SOW dashboard customized for users focused on financials and spend task management. Alt Text: A screenshot of SOW Dashboard showing four cards “SOW with Largest Budgets”, “Deviations in Actual Spend”, “SOW Spend & Duration Alterts”, and “SOW Revisions”. The first two are represented as charts, the other two as lists.

SOW AI-Assisted Document Extraction

No matter how good the software, having to manually copy data from a document into a system to create a Statement of Work (SOW) does not rank as a great experience for most people! Now, we have significantly improved the user experience by leveraging generative AI to automate a lot of this work.

SAP Fieldglass has integrated SAP Document AI, so that users can automate the extraction and transformation of statement of work content from uploaded documents. This combined AI approach parses the source files, identifies relevant content, and generates a structured, accurate draft statement of work, reducing manual effort while improving data consistency and completeness. Figure 10 shows how users now have the new AI-enabled workflow option for creating a statement of work.

Figure 11: New AI-enabled option for creating a statement of work in SAP Fieldglass. Alt Text: A screenshot of a pop-over “Create Statement of Work” containing two clickable cards: on the left “Standard Workflow” and description “Manually enter and select the details for this Statement of Work”, on the right with an AI icon “Upload Document Workflow” and description “Select a file for AI to read and populate Statement of Work details.”

Once the document has been processed, you can open the drafted statement of work to view the outcome: the AI icon appears next to sections of the document to indicate fields with content extracted using AI.

Find out more in the documentation:

  • Documentation: SOW DOX (Document Extraction).

entry.title: Sourcing & Procurement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Sourcing & Procurement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508

 

Hello Everyone,

With the 2508 release of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the Sourcing and Procurement line of business continues to evolve, bringing forward innovations that empower procurement professionals to operate with greater agility, transparency, and collaboration. This release focuses on enhancing core procurement processes, integrating intelligent technologies, and improving user experience across the board. Let’s take a closer look at the key updates and how they support your procurement transformation journey.

 

For other releases please see here. Check out all demos in a playlist here.

Operational Procurement

  • Document Management System attachments on the purchase requisition header
  • Ability to provide ad hoc approver for purchase order workflow
  • Reviewer workflow for purchase order approval
  • Enhanced account assignment categories as start conditions for purchase order workflow
  • V4 API for intracompany stock transfer
  • Maintenance of supplier confirmation notes
  • Enable account assignment category Q in Manage Purchase Contracts App
  • Extensibility in manage source lists app
  • Viewing distributed value still to be invoiced in the purchase order items by account assignment app

SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management

  • Input tax – Calculation, verification, and validation using external tax engines

SAP Arabia Central Procurement

  • Enablement of single-line distributions from central purchase contracts
  • Procurement Expansion Package

 

 

Sourcing and Procurement in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

Document Management System attachments on the purchase requisition header

The integration of the Document Management System (DMS) at the header level of purchase requisitions marks a significant improvement in how procurement teams manage documentation. Professional purchasers can now attach relevant documents directly to requisitions, with the ability to classify them for internal or external use. While external classification will be supported in future updates, the current functionality already streamlines documentation processes and ensures consistency across SAP Fiori applications such as “Manage Purchase Requisition – Professional” and “Create Purchase Requisition – Advanced.” This enhancement simplifies audit trails, improves traceability, and fosters better collaboration between procurement teams and stakeholders.

 

For more information, see: Manage Purchase Requisitions - Professional

Ability to provide ad hoc approver for purchase order workflow

Procurement workflows often require flexibility, especially when exceptional circumstances arise. The introduction of ad-hoc approvers allows authorized users to dynamically add individuals to a workflow instance based on the context of a specific purchase order. This capability ensures that critical decisions are not delayed due to rigid approval chains. The ability to designate multiple ad-hoc approvers and track their involvement in the approval history adds a layer of transparency and responsiveness, making procurement processes more agile and context-aware.

 

For more information, see:  Manage Purchase Orders 

Reviewer workflow for purchase order approval

SAP has introduced a reviewer step in purchase order workflows, allowing designated users to monitor workflow progress and provide feedback without having approval authority. This feature is particularly valuable for organizations that require compliance checks, financial oversight, or legal reviews before finalizing purchases. By enabling user-based or role-based recipient selection and allowing deadline settings, SAP ensures that the review process is both structured and adaptable. This innovation enhances governance and fosters a collaborative approach to procurement decision-making.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders

Enhanced account assignment categories as start conditions for purchase order workflow

The ability to use account assignment categories—such as Internal Order, Asset, and Sales Order—as workflow triggers provides organizations with granular control over procurement approvals. These categories can now be defined as start conditions for purchase order workflows, allowing organizations to tailor approval processes based on financial responsibility and operational context. Additionally, step conditions can be configured to assign specific individuals responsible for each category, ensuring that approvals are targeted and relevant. This supports better financial stewardship and operational alignment.

 

For more information, see:  Manage Workflows for Purchase Orders

 

V4 API for intracompany stock transfer

SAP’s introduction of a new OData V4 API for intracompany stock transfers enables external applications to create, read, update, and delete stock transport orders in real time. This API-driven approach supports seamless integration with external systems, facilitating efficient stock movement across organizational units and enhancing data accuracy. The inclusion of error messaging ensures that invalid data is promptly flagged, reducing the risk of discrepancies and improving overall inventory control.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Stock Transport Order (CE_STOCKTRANSPORTORDER_0001) and Stock Transport Order (OData V4)

Maintenance of supplier confirmation notes

Supplier collaboration is enhanced through the automatic integration of supplier confirmation notes into purchase orders. When suppliers provide notes during the confirmation process, these are now automatically transferred to the corresponding purchase order and its items. This ensures that supplier input is accurately captured and reflected throughout the procurement lifecycle. By reducing manual data entry and minimizing the risk of miscommunication, this feature improves order accuracy and strengthens supplier relationships.

 

For more information, see: Manage Supplier Confirmations

Enable account assignment category Q in Manage Purchase Contracts App

Project-based procurement receives a boost with the inclusion of account assignment category Q (project stock) in the Manage Purchase Contract app. This enables organizations to handle make-to-order scenarios with greater precision, including the management of fields such as WBS elements and GL accounts. By extending support to project procurement, SAP empowers industries like construction, engineering, and manufacturing to align purchasing activities with project timelines and budgets.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see:  Manage Purchase Contracts

Extensibility in manage source lists app

The Manage Source List app has been enhanced to support custom fields, allowing users to store business-specific information that aids in sourcing decisions. Previously, the app did not permit the addition of custom fields, limiting its flexibility. With the new capability, users can define fields of various types—such as string, date, and decimal—and manage them using provided BADIs. This extensibility supports tailored data management and improves the efficiency of source list maintenance.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Manage Source Lists and Overview of Changes in Extensibility Objects

Viewing distributed value still to be invoiced in the purchase order items by account assignment app

Financial transparency is further improved with the ability to view pending invoice values distributed across account assignment splits in purchase order items. When a purchase order item is assigned to multiple cost objects, such as cost centers or internal orders, users can now monitor the open invoice amount proportionally per assignment line. This granular visibility supports accurate accruals, budget tracking, and financial reporting, enabling organizations to maintain tighter control over their expenditures.

 

 

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Purchase Order Items by Account Assignment 

Procurement Expansion Package

The Procurement Expansion Package (PEP) consolidates advanced operational procurement features, catalog content channels, and supplier network capabilities into a single offering. Designed for SAP Cloud ERP customers, PEP delivers comprehensive spend coverage, improved compliance, and enhanced supplier collaboration. It supports a consumer-grade shopping experience, touchless supplier interactions, and end-to-end visibility across procurement processes. By digitizing manual transactions and centralizing procurement data, PEP helps organizations achieve greater efficiency, transparency, and strategic value.

 

For more information, see: Manage Central Purchase Contracts

 

Sourcing and Procurement in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management

Input tax – Calculation, verification, and validation using external tax engines

Tax compliance is a critical aspect of procurement, and SAP addresses this through integration with external tax engines like Vertex and Thomson Reuters in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management. This integration allows for the calculation, verification, and validation of VAT, GST, and other transaction taxes on supplier invoices. By automating tax determination and comparison with supplier-provided data, organizations can prevent overpayments, mitigate compliance risks, and enhance audit readiness. The ability to specify commodity codes and use address data for tax calculation further refines the accuracy of this process.

 

 

For more information, see: Verification of Tax Applied to a Supplier Invoice

Sourcing and Procurement in SAP Ariba Central Procurement

Enablement of single-line distributions from central purchase contracts

Central procurement capabilities have been expanded in two key areas. First, the activation of single-line distribution within central contracts allows organizations to generate individual outline agreements for each contract line item. This is particularly beneficial for industries such as automotive, where scheduling agreements often require single-item configurations. Second, when copying a central contract, users can now edit fields such as supplier and purchasing organization, providing greater flexibility in contract lifecycle management and enabling smoother transitions when suppliers change.

 

 

 

 

For more information, see: Manage Central Purchase Contracts

entry.title: SAP Ariba 使用技巧和最佳实践：客制和优化策略
entry.content:
客制技巧

  1. 定制用户页面：定制用户页面，满足企业的品牌和工作流需求。这包括更新系统中品牌的设置、枚举和字段配置
  2. 配置审批工作流: 设置于您的组织架构和支出阈值一直的审批规则。这可确保有有效地审核和审批采购申请和订单。
  3. 创建自定义报告：开发自定义报告以跟踪关键绩效指标（KPI）和采购指标。这有助于监控绩效并制定明智的决策。

优化策略

  1. 利用AI选择供应商：使用SAP Ariba中基于AI的工具，根据您的特定需求选择最佳供应商。这有助于降低成本，提高供应商绩效。

entry.title: Unlocking the Potential of Artificial Intelligence in Enhancing User Experience in SAP Guided Buying
entry.content:
Hi there and welcome to my latest blog. 

My name is Angeline Gregory, I am one of the Solution Value Advisors based in the UK.  The world of procurement is continuously evolving, and with it are the tools and technologies aimed at optimizing organizational spend.  Here, I am excited to present my blog on how artificial intelligence can elevate the user experience in SAP Guided Buying.

SAP Guided Buying can steer users towards more efficient and compliant buying processes.  It is crucial to integrate advanced technologies such as Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) into your buying processes to enrich the experience.

The below features in SAP Guided Buying make purchasing decisions smoother and smarter and hence improve cost effectiveness and increases compliance.

Catalog Item Recommendation

The item recommendation feature suggests products and services based on users' past purchases.  It collects purchasing history from your organization and uses artificial intelligence to recommend catalog items that might be of interest based on the individual user. Item recommendations display in a carousel at the top of the home page, in the item details page or as alternatives to non-catalog item.

This feature improves productivity by:

  • Encouraging usage of catalog item when creating a non-catalog request​
  • Reducing effort when searching for items​
  • Reducing distractions when browsing
  • Improving user experience ​

Enable this feature by turning on the below parameters in SAP Guided Buying:

  • PARAM_ENABLE_ITEM_RECOMMENDATIONS
  • PARAM_ENABLE_CLICKSTREAM_PUBLISH

Note:

  • This feature is embedded AI-Feature included in your Guided Buying subscription 
  • At first SAP Guided Buying will show “Popular Items” based on organization’s most frequent purchases.  AI will learn and start showing “Recommended for you” items / services based on users clicks​.

Guided Buying Usage Report

The usage report in Guided Buying gives administrators insight into user searches, purchases, and overall interaction with SAP Guided Buying. SAP Guided Buying generates this report monthly to provides usage details, such as the number of users who signed in, number of users who added items to their cart, total number of items added to carts, and searches that returned no results.  This report helps answer business questions like which catalog areas to expand and the most popular search items.  By leveraging the insights from the Usage Report, organizations can continuously improve user experience based on data.

This feature improves efficiency by:

  • Highlighting opportunities based on user behavior, search patterns​ and search effectiveness analysis​
  • Aids making catalog improvements and helps bring spend under management​
  • Providing evidence- to make quicker design decisions

Enable this feature by turning on the below parameters in SAP Guided Buying:

  • PARAM_ENABLE_USAGE_REPORTS
  • PARAM_ENABLE_CLICKSTREAM_PUBLISH

Note:

  • ​This feature is embedded AI-Feature included in your Guided Buying subscription
  • SAP Guided Buying generates reports only after at least 100 unique users have cumulatively clicked “Add to cart” more than 1,000 times.  It must first collect and analyze a significant number of searching and purchasing actions 

​By using these features in guided buying systems, organizations can significantly help shape the way users buy goods or services.

Integrating AI and ML into guided buying isn't just about improving technology; it's about strategically enhancing the procurement process better suited to users' needs, while staying compliant and cost effective.

So, whether you are just starting out or looking to refine your procurement processes, consider how AI and ML can make a significant impact on your organization's guided buying system and watch as your bottom line and operational efficiencies improve.

entry.title: How Personal Spending Habits Mirror Enterprise Procurement
entry.content:
Introduction

When it comes to managing our personal finances, most of us intuitively follow certain steps to control spending and save more. Interestingly, these same steps closely mirror the structured procurement processes that enterprises use to manage spend at scale.

To illustrate, let’s start with a simple personal example and then see how it aligns with enterprise procurement practices.

Personal Spend and Saving: A Simple Thought Process

Imagine you want to save more money this month. You realize there are two main ways to do that:

  1. Increase your income.       ⬆️
  2. Reduce your expenses.     ⬇️

Let’s focus on reducing expenses.

This logical sequence helps you save money while still ensuring your family’s needs are met.

How This Mirrors Enterprise Procurement

At the enterprise level, procurement follows the same flow—only it’s structured, automated, and scaled to handle greater complexity.

 

Personal Spend ExampleEnterprise Procurement Process
Classify expenses (e.g., groceries)Spend Classification: Categorize spend into goods and services like IT equipment, raw materials, or consulting services.
Analyze where you spend the mostSpend Analysis: Identify high-spend areas and uncover potential savings opportunities.
Search for vendorsSourcing: Conduct market research, invite bids (RFPs), and evaluate supplier capabilities.
Negotiate and select a vendorContracting: Negotiate terms (price, quality, delivery) and create legal contracts to formalize agreements.
Receive daily apple deliveryCataloging & Purchase Request: Maintain supplier catalogs for easy ordering and raise purchase requests as needed.
Receive invoice at month-endPurchase Order & Receipt: Issue purchase orders, confirm goods/services received, and match them with the invoice.
Pay the vendorInvoicing & Payment: Process, approve, and execute payments through financial systems.

Conclusion

Managing personal finances may seem worlds apart from enterprise procurement, but the underlying principles are remarkably similar. Both rely on classification, sourcing, negotiation, purchase, and payment to optimize spend while meeting essential needs.

The next time you shop for apples, you’re not just budgeting - you’re practicing procurement on a personal scale.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Procurement Solutions for Lifesciences & Healthcare customers
entry.content:
In this post, we consider a common usecase for pharmaceutical companies: the procurement of Active Pharmaceutical Ingredients (APIs) from approved contract manufacturers (CMO) or suppliers.

User Story

As a production planner in a mid-size pharmaceutical company, I need to procure an API only from approved manufacturers (CMO), verify the regulatory documents for completeness, correctness, and validity, so that the purchase can be processed without compliance risks or delays.

Personas Involved

  • Production Planner (using MM on ERP)
  • Category Buyer (Using  SAP Ariba Category Management )
  • Quality Assurance Approver (using SAP Ariba Supplier Lifecycle and Performance & SAP Ariba Supplier Risk )
  • Supplier Manufacturer (using the SAP Business Network for Suppliers )
  • Supplier Risk Analyst (using SAP Ariba Supplier Risk)
  • AP Invoice Processor (SAP Ariba Invoicing

System Recommendations & Assumptions

  • Supplier/Contract Manufacturer can be sourced using Ariba Guided Sourcing and onboarded using SAP Ariba SLP , continuously monitored for risks (ESG, financial, regulatory, etc.) using SAP Ariba Supplier Risk.

 

  • Possibility to invite customers for a sourcing event in   SAP Ariba Sourcing, based on their qualification and risk status as well as ability to fulfill the business n
  • At the end of the sourcing event, a supplier will be selected.

The Supplier 360 dashboard on SLP can be used to view supplier details.

  • Suppliers can be qualified and registered using SLP, where status, certification information, risk information, etc., can be maintained and viewed. GxP relevant certificates (GMP certificate, DMF/CEP references, country-specific permits) can be used for supplier qualification.
  • Contracts can be created using baseline contract templates in Ariba.
  • The API material can be maintained in ERP with a unique material code. Manufacturer’s substance codes and parent-child code mappings can also be maintained in ERP.

End-to-end Flow ( Considering PR originates in ERP, for direct material procurement) 

  • ERP:
    • MRP run creates a PR for API-12345 for supplier AKME Systems for 50 kgs with a delivery deadline of 4 weeks
  • PR Sent to Ariba Buying/Guided Buying :
    • The PR is sent to Ariba Buying/Guided Buying for collaboration and approvals.
    • Information related to parent-child codes mapping, a reference list of approved suppliers, etc. is also sent.
  • Category Buyer Review :
    • The category buyer in Ariba Guided Buying reviews the PR and confirms the supplier/manufacturer pairing.
    • Custom fields display required information like manufacturer's codes, parent code, DMF, etc.
  • QA Approval :
    • As part of QA approval, following checks could be considered: 
      • Ensuring the CMO/supplier is approved in SLP and not expired,
      • Verification parent-child codes match the ERP records,
      • Validation of country permits,
      • Verification of other documents and certificates like GXP relevant, FDA approval, etc.

            If all checks are fine, then PR will be approved, else returned with comments. 

  • PO Creation in Ariba Guided Buying : 
    • A PO is created in Guided Buying and sent to the supplier via SAP Business Network / SCC.
    • It is possible to add conditions to ensure that no PO is created without QA approval. 

Ariba Buying for creating PO

  • Supplier Confirmation via SAP Business Network/SCC:
    • The supplier confirms PO quantities and delivery dates. 
    • Provides a shipment plan and ASN (Advance Ship Notice) with batch number, expected lot (UoM), CoA (Certificate of Analysis), other certificates relevant for GMP, export/import permits, etc. 

SAP Business Network

Supplier can also proactively create Quality Notifications in SAP Business Network / SCC, in order to communicate to the buyer about quality issues like defects in the products, non-confirming items, etc. 

  • S/4HANA or ERP Processing : 
    • The integration with S/4 HANA ensures that the confirmation and ASN data is received by the production planner.
    • The Quality Assurance Approver also receives notification using QM. 
  • Goods Receipt in S/4HANA :
    • GR is posted by the warehouse for received batches.
  • Supplier PO-Flip on the SAP Business Network/SCC :
    • The supplier can perform PO-flip and send the invoice electronically. 
    • Ariba Invoicing runs 3-way match (PO,GR,Invoice). If the match is successful, invoice is posted for payment. 
  • Auditing and Reporting : 
    • An audit trail of approvals, documents and timestamps is maintained for auditing and reporting purpose in Ariba.
    • integration with SAP Analytics Dashboard also helps the buyer in accessing analytical reports and checking various metrics. 
  • Continuous Risk Monitoring :
    • SAP Ariba Supplier Risk performs 24/7 monitoring for geopolitical risks, social & environmental risks, financial risks like bankruptcy, cyber threats, sanctions list changes, etc. 
    • Alerts are raised for risk situation changes, supplier status changes, etc. based on the configuration of users. An alternate supplier can be recommended based on the qualified suppliers listed for the same category. 

SAP Ariba Supplier Risk

Please read my blogs Boosting Procurement Efficiency in 2024 with SAP Ariba Supplier Risk & Best Practices for effective supplier risk management with SAP Ariba for more information on SAP Ariba Supplier Risk.

To conclude, SAP Ariba, integrated with SAP S/4HANA, offers a comprehensive solution for the life sciences and healthcare industry, addressing the complexities of API procurement. By leveraging these tools, companies can enhance supplier management, compliance, efficiency, and overall supply chain resilience.

Stay tuned for our next blog, where we will explore how SAP Ariba procurement solutions could help with the compliance requirements of regulated industries like life sciences and healthcare.

entry.title: Learn more about Fiscalization 2.0 in Croatia: e-invoicing (B2B) , fiscalization and e-reporting
entry.content:
Regulatory Changes  
As part of the "Fiscalization 2.0" project and starting January 2026, the Croatian government is introducing B2B e-invoicing, e-reporting and fiscalization requirements. 

  • B2B/B2G e-invoicing: all businesses with VAT registration in Croatia need to send electronic invoices in the required format through an approved service provider.
  • Fiscalization: 
    • B2B/B2G invoices: issuer and receiver of e-invoices need to send the fiscal data of the invoice to authorities (digitally signed XML). 
    • B2C invoices: issuer of the e-invoice needs to send fiscal to authorities irrespective of payment method (currently required only for cash payments). 
  • E-reporting: in addition to invoicing data (fiscalization), the following reporting requirements need to be fulfilled: 
    • List of collected invoices (payment received), during reporting period (month) for invoice issuer. 
    • List of outbound deliveries for which e-invoice could not be delivered, during reporting period (month) for invoice issuer. 
    • List of rejected invoices, during reporting period (month) for invoice recipient.

entry.title: Tax Code and Amount Not Transferring from SAP to Ariba – Root Cause and Solution
entry.content:
In some situations, suppliers are required to upload and submit their invoices directly through SAP Ariba. Once submitted, these invoices are automatically transferred into SAP S/4HANA for approval and posting.

One of the challenges we’ve identified is that suppliers are required to manually maintain the tax code and taxable amount for every invoice uploaded in Ariba. This approach is far from ideal, it increases the risk of discrepancies and inconsistencies across invoices.

In this post, I’ll Walk through a solution to address this issue and make the process more accurate, reliable, and efficient.

The issue arises from missing configuration in SAP and incomplete mapping in the integration between SAP and Ariba. Tax details are expected to be transferred through IDocs; however, in this case, the IDocs are not carrying the tax details, 

It is important to note that tax details consist of: Tax code, Tax rate, Taxable amount, and Tax amount.
All of these elements must be accurately transferred and calculated in both SAP and Ariba to ensure the reliability and accuracy of tax invoices submitted by suppliers through the Ariba portal.
Any missing element could potentially lead to the tax details not being transferred accurately.

All Tax details should be transferred from the PO in SAP ERP system to Ariba automatically,

To achieve this, configuration must be done in SAP ERP and in Ariba,

  1. In SAP ERP:
  • For Material PO: send Tax code, Tax rate and Tax amount under E1EDP01/E1EDPO4 and taxable amount under E1EDP01/E1EDPO5.

 

E1EDP01/E1EDPO4 should transfer the below details 

 

E1EDP01/E1EDPO5 should transfer the below details

 

  • For Service PO: send the Tax code, Tax rate and Tax amount under E1EDPO1/E1EDC01/E1EDC04 and taxable amount under E1EDPO1/E1EDC01/E1EDC05

 

E1EDPO1/E1EDC01/E1EDC04 should transfer the below details

 

E1EDPO1/E1EDC01/E1EDC05 should transfer the below details

 

This configuration ensures that The tax code will be transmitted at the child line-item level of the PO in addition to the main line-item level.

This ensures that tax is calculated for each individual child line item, while maintaining consistency at the main item level.  

Please be aware that the configuration of the Tax details at the main item level should remain as well. 

The tax structure in the PO as it is sent to Ariba should be reflected as follows:

 

  1. In Ariba: Mapping is not possible for this via CIG mapping tool; XSLT mapping should be done.
  • For the service PO: The Payload for the outbound and the pre-processed files of the PO should transfer all tax details as below

                <E1EDC05 SEGMENT="1">
                    <KSCHL>BASB</KSCHL>
                    <KOBTR>500</KOBTR>
                </E1EDC05>

            <E1EDP04 SEGMENT="1">

            </E1EDP05>

entry.title: What is Adoption?
entry.content:
As a former customer turned SAP employee dedicated to adoption, I hear some very different ideas about what adoption actually is.  It seems to mean something very different to almost every customer I’ve spoken with (over 100 at this point)!  So let’s clear the fog and attempt to create a working definition of adoption!

_______________________________________________________________

First, What Adoption Is Not

  • Not just the starting line. Marathon running for instance involves preparation, a starting line, a finish line, and in between a lot of hard work. Similarly, the day you “go live” is the starting line, not the finish line. You have to run the entire race!
  • Not “our users seem happy.” Sentiment is helpful but measurable business outcomes are the stuff of gold medals.
  • Not just a dashboard of random metrics. 1,000 logins are great but 3 automated processes that cut cycle time in half are better.
  • Not a once-and-done project. As your business, your processes, and your roadmap evolve; adoption is a continuous discipline.

_______________________________________________________________

So… What Is Adoption?

Adoption is the strategic, ongoing process of turning your SAP software into everyday business results. It goes beyond initial deployment to drive full, meaningful engagement across your organization—so you realize the value you bought, renew with confidence, and double-down on what works. Let’s review adoption as three components.

1) Depth and Breadth of Usage

Great adoption means your team uses the right capabilities deeply—and enough teams use them broadly—to create enterprise-wide impact.

  • Depth: You’re not just approving POs or reviewing timesheets—you’re using game- changing features like Guided Buying for SAP Ariba or SOW Bid for SAP Fieldglass. The features & functions that move the needle are the ones tied to specific value drivers such as price reduction, efficiency, quality, and compliance.
  • Breadth: Procurement, Finance, Operations, HR, and field teams all participate making workflows across what was once a silo’d organization. Swivel chair processes are gone. Handoffs are digital, not manual.

Signs you’re winning:

  • Feature usage moves from “core” capabilities to advanced.
  • Multiple business areas participate in end‑to‑end workflows (not isolated tasks).
  • Efficiency metrics improve: cycle time ↓, rework ↓, compliance ↑.

Benefit: Your process becomes a case study in total transformation not just another software deployment.

2) Consumption Aligned to Entitlement

You’ve matched what you own (spend/users/modules) with what you actually use—so value is realized, not left on the table.

  • You avoid shelfware by activating high‑value modules you’ve already paid for (and most likely justified with a business case).
  • Usage equals value. Your consumption patterns justify renewals and make the case for expansion.

Signs you’re winning:

  • License utilization aligns with the contract & business need.
  • Shelfware is activated with a plan.
  • Stakeholders can see a clear story of investing “x” to get “y”.

Benefit: The ROI is predictable & justified from a budget perspective because results are tangible.

3) Value Achieved

Adoption is measured by business results, not just the number of logins.

  • Efficiency: cycle time, touchless processing.
  • Compliance: policy adherence and audit readiness.
  • Cost/price: realized savings and cost avoidance.
  • Quality: candidates for SAP Fieldglass are up to the challenge

Signs you’re winning:

  • KPIs tie to executive priorities.
  • Value is repeatable and attributable to specific SAP-enabled scenarios.
  • Leaders want to know, “What else can we automate?”

Benefit: SAP solutions become an engine for transformation and growth. SAP is a valued and trusted partner.

_______________________________________________________________

A Practical 90‑Day Adoption Game Plan

  1. Start with value. Identify 3–5 outcomes (e.g., reduce invoice cycle time by 30%, increase spend under management by 15%).
  2. Map value to capability. Which capabilities make those outcomes real? (e.g., SAP Fieldglass Rate guidance or SOW bids.  SAP Ariba Guided Buying, a well-defined supplier risk process.)
  3. Activate champions by role. Procurement, AP, HR, and Operations, each need a champion with a playbook and a plan.
  4. Configure KPIs & measure them early so you can see adoption in real time.
  5. Show the score. Publish a simple, clear scorecard; spotlight improvements and highlight bottlenecks.
  6. Scale what works. Turn the first wins into success stories; communicate and repeat what works across teams/regions.
  7. Run regular adoption health checks. Which areas of the business need more help? Who deserves an innovation award?

_______________________________________________________________

Adoption done right . . .

So how are you running the race of adoption? Does your preparation phase need help? Do you need help getting from mile 13 to 20? When adoption is done right, your SAP solutions become the way your business runs—faster, smarter, with endurance & purpose.

entry.content:
The Future of Procurement: Unlocking Value Through Business Accelerators with Klaus Fischer

In today’s rapidly evolving business landscape, procurement is no longer just a back-office function—it’s a strategic driver of growth, resilience, and innovation. This was the central theme of a recent episode of SAP’s “The Future of Procurement Podcast,” featuring Klaus Fischer, a veteran SAP leader and board advisor, whose career has spanned engineering, consulting, and transformative acquisitions. Fischer’s insights offer a roadmap for organizations seeking to unlock value by bridging finance and procurement, embracing technology, and fostering collaboration.

🏛️ From Engineering to Boardroom: The Journey of Transformation

Klaus Fischer’s story is emblematic of the evolution within procurement. Starting at SAP’s headquarters in Germany, Fischer’s career journey led him from engineering to strategic advisory roles, culminating in his pivotal involvement in SAP’s acquisition of Ariba—a move that redefined spend management and procurement for the enterprise. By integrating Ariba’s cloud-based capabilities with SAP’s robust ERP solutions, Fischer helped create a seamless, end-to-end platform that empowers organizations to optimize spend, drive compliance, and build resilient supply chains.

🔗 Breaking Down Silos: The Power of Finance and Procurement Alignment

A recurring theme in the discussion was the critical need for CFOs and CPOs to break down organizational silos. In a climate marked by low growth, high costs, and regulatory complexity, Fischer emphasized that external pressures—geopolitical shifts, tariffs, inflation, and supply chain disruptions—demand agile, integrated responses. Internal challenges, such as data silos and manual processes, further hinder agility. The solution? Unified platforms and processes that connect finance and procurement, enabling real-time decision-making and accelerating value realization.

🚀 Business Accelerators: Unlocking Value Quickly

Fischer introduced the concept of “business accelerators”—strategic initiatives that rapidly unlock value across finance and procurement. Mastering working capital, for example, is more critical than ever. By connecting invoice-to-pay and invoice-to-cash processes, organizations can optimize cash flow, reduce risk, and improve key performance indicators like day sales outstanding (DSO) and day payable outstanding (DPO). Change management and governance are essential to overcoming resistance and ensuring successful adoption of new technologies and processes.

🤖 AI and Unified Data: The Next Frontier

Looking ahead, Fischer identified AI-powered automation and unified data as game-changers for procurement and finance. SAP’s embedded AI capabilities—spanning category management, guided sourcing, spend visibility, and financial close—enable organizations to achieve dramatic improvements in speed, accuracy, and strategic outcomes. The trustworthiness and precision of enterprise AI are paramount, especially when managing complex, high-value transactions.

📈 Real-World Outcomes and Forward-Looking Insights

When finance and procurement teams collaborate, companies realize tangible benefits: optimized savings, reduced risk, improved compliance, and more effective supplier onboarding. End-to-end workflows and internal controls ensure consistency and resilience, even amid global disruptions. Fischer’s forward-looking advice for leaders? Embrace agentic AI, automation, and integrated business processes to stay ahead in 2026 and beyond.

💡 Conclusion: Procurement Never Sleeps—Neither Should Your Ideas

As organizations navigate uncertainty and transformation, the alignment of finance and procurement, powered by technology and strategic leadership, will be the key to unlocking sustainable growth. The future of procurement is collaborative, data-driven, and relentlessly innovative. What accelerators will your organization pursue next?

Share your thoughts, feedback, and ideas as we continue exploring the future of procurement together.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Procure to Order 2511 Release Key Innovations
entry.content:
Hello SAP Ariba Community, We're thrilled to share great new innovations in our upcoming release, 2511 with a strong focus on improved management of service requisitioning and overall UX improvements in Guided Buying. We are also pleased to share expanded capability in SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile app and improved user experience for catalog administrators, we hope you enjoy the highlights.

Support for Hierarchical Service Items in Guided Buying (GUIDEB-300)

Complex service procurements (for example, a laptop repair plus software maintenance and a parts kit) traditionally generate multiple requisitions, follow‑ups and approval cycles.

Service hierarchies let your teams create a single, coherent requisition that models the real delivery structure of work and items. That reduces administrative overhead, shortens cycle time to order, and gives finance and procurement better visibility into bundled spend — all of which translate to faster time-to-value and lower operational cost.

Child items can include catalog and non-catalog services or goods. For example, you can create a non-catalog request for laptop repair service (parent service) and then add software maintenance service (child item) and computer cleaning kit (child item).

Service hierarchies help to define how services are structured and delivered, improving efficiency when ordering services.

You can use service hierarchies in the following scenarios:

  • When you create a service requisition using a non-catalog request or a line item form, you can add child items using the Add Child Item button.
  • On the checkout page, you can add child items to the request before you submit it.
  • If you submit a service requistion, you can withdraw it after it's submitted or partially approved, add child items, and then resubmit it.

When you create a non-catalog request for a service, the Add Child Item button, Expected Amount, and Max Amount display on the form, as shown in the following figure:

 The following figure displays a hierarchical service request:

 

This feature can be enabled through the following parameter:

PARAM_ENABLE_NON_CATALOG_SERVICE_HIERARCHY which enables service hierarchies for non-catalog requests and line item forms.

 

Hide Interim Supplier RFQ Bids (GUIDEB-1262)

You can now configure Guided Buying to hide interim supplier RFQ bids from users and display only awarded bids.

By default, guided buying displays all bids to users. However, taking onboard your feedback, some customers may prefer to hide interim bids and display only the winning bid after it has been awarded.

This capability is available only in high-touch RFQ scenarios, where professional buyers evaluate and award bids in SAP Ariba Sourcing.

If you enable this feature there will be some subtle changes to the UI in the following screens:

  • Receive quotes
  • Awarding
  • Confirm award
  • Bid overview section
  • Compare bids (both graph and table view)

You can enable this capability by setting a new guided buying parameter PARAM_ENABLE_HIDE_BIDS_IN_HIGH_TOUCH to true.

For more information about configuring API communication, see Guided Buying Parameters for RFQs

 

Display Requisition Amount in Approver's or Watcher's Currency (PROC-1029)

Given the global nature of business these days it's quite likely approvers may be overseas, to simplify this experience for an approver we have introduced the ability to display requisition amount upon approval in the approver (or watchers) preferred/default currency.

New fields such as Total in Your Currency at the header level and Amount in Your Currency at the line level are displayed for a requisition when the requisition is sent for approval:

 Your administrator can enable the through the following parameter: PARAM_ENABLE_APPROVERS_AMOUNT_IN_LOCAL_CURRENCY

 

Support for Budget Check in External ERP System for SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile App Requisitions (BMAA-479)

Its always important to know if your cost centre has sufficient budget to allow your requisition and corresponding PO to be created. We have now expanded requisition budget check capability to the SAP Ariba Procurement Mobile app too.

In the SAP Ariba Procurement mobile app, real-time budget check is performed in the external ERP system (normally the source to check the budget against the requisition) when users submit or withdraw requisitions, and also when requisitions are approved or denied.

To enable this capability your administrator can enable the parameter: Application.Mobile.EnableRTBCInExternalERPSystem

 

Enhancements to Catalog Replication Page (CMS-1418)

With this feature, the Catalog Replication page contains a new tab called Content that allows catalog administrators to search for catalogs quickly. The new design optimizes browsing and viewing large volumes of data.

Previously, the Catalog Replication page loaded all the catalogs in the Overview and Configuration tabs, which made it difficult for users to search for catalogs.

A new tab called Content is now displayed on the Catalog Replication page. As a catalog administrator, you can search for a catalog by its name and type (subscribed or unsubscribed). By default, the number of catalogs displayed on the page is limited to 1000.

We are happy today to have covered an important set of features to benefit end users, approvers and also catalog administrators with the aim to streamline work by presenting the right information front and centre to get the job done quickly and efficiently throughout the buying process.
